segments.text: Thinking about some of the things that your dad enjoyed doing.
Yes.
Go ahead.
And truly, if he had time, he was wanting to be with friends.
And certainly at the top of that list would be Maggie McGee.
From Fort Worth.
No, Houston.
Houston.
Maggie was president of Tenneco Pipeline.
Oh, that's right.
That's right.
at some point was president of former students.
Now, what year was that?
That was in the 60s.
But he and dad remained friends forever.
And some of the nicest trips that mother and dad got to take were with the McGees.
And they traveled together and always were doing good things for A&M, I think, wherever they went.
And Congressman Teague.
Yes.
And Dad didn't get to see him as much just because of the distance between D.C. and here.
But their friendship went way, way, way back to student days, didn't it?
It did.
I don't, you know, people like Lupo could really tell.
And, you know, of course, Lupo was Mr. Teague's roommate.
But Mr. Lupo would tell you that, you know, he said, I really wasn't your dad's good friend, even though they were classmates.
Mm-hmm.
But they were not as well acquainted as Dad.
Because I've heard an anecdote that I haven't tried to follow up on, but that, let's see, Lupo got in trouble for taking a rap from Mr. Teague's alcohol in the dorm room or something like that.
Oh, I didn't know.
I didn't know that.
I didn't know that.
And that may have been a Lupo story.
All right, if your dad were going to invite a group of buddies, friends,
over to the house for an enjoyable evening.
And he was making up the guest list.
Who do you think would have been on?
Maggie McGee and who else?
Maggie and Sally.
Dad always stayed in touch.
MJ Green had been his best friend from Eden, Texas.
Best man in each other's wedding.
There was a painter, was one of his classmates, John Miller.
Now do you mean a house painter or an artist painter?
Well, he painted billboards.
But apparently MJ Green and John Miller and my dad were just the best chums from Eden, Texas.
And I can remember talking to dad about what made him do some of the things.
And I think that group, or the competition of a group of young friends,
He said, I just couldn't stand for them to be able to do something I couldn't do better.
I think that young boy competition, but he always stayed.
Anytime we'd go to the ranch, we'd stop by Buchanan, which was where John Miller had settled.
Now when he'd go to the ranch, what did he check on first?
We got the part of the land that had the old family home.
So my granny and papa's mother's folks home is part of ours.
And so you'd check on the house, you'd check on the water, you'd check on the barns, you'd check on, then you'd get in the pickup.
And the kids always got to ride in the back of the pickup.
And if it was hunting season, it was our job to beat on the top if we spotted a deer.
But he would just
He just loved driving the pastures.
And as he was driving the pastures, he was checking on the water supply, the quality of the grass.
I can remember him telling me about after the drought in the 50s, and all the cattle had to be shipped, and they had been Herefords prior to that, and O.D.
Butler.
helped Dad restock the ranch after that and recommended Black Angus.
And I can remember a lesson in judging cattle and what fine beef these were.
And what did he have before Black Angus?
The Herefords, the Whiteface.
He was really happy out there.
I can remember him chasing rattlesnakes.
And he truly, he didn't do, I guess he'd grown up doing it.
I can remember him driving in the car and if a train was coming by, he'd race it.
There were just a lot of kind of neat things that he did his whole life.
All right, let's make believe you and your mom are gonna plan his favorite meal.
Oh, his favorite meal.
Probably roast beef or steak.
He was not a big one for vegetables.
And he had a sweet tooth that I think we all inherited.
He loved good food and good friends gathered around and the kids.
Would there have been any mashed potatoes and gravy?
Mashed potatoes and gravy, chicken fried steak, you bet.
Fried chicken.
Fried chicken, sweet tooth.
What kind of pie or cake?
Pecan pie.
Mother used to make lots of desserts.
She'd make a lemon meringue and a chocolate meringue and chocolate cake.
Grandmother Roddy was a wonderful cook.
And the ranch was a ranch.
It wasn't farming.
It was ranching.
Right.
And in both your parents, they grew up in ranching.
country.
And if I were to ask your dad geographically what part of Texas Eden was in, what would he say?
You know, West Texas.
He would have said West Texas.
West Texas.
Geographically, McCullough County just next is the geographic center by a lot of measurements of the state of Texas.
And now it's considered to be the hill country.
Now Menard County is the
western edge of the hill country.
But he would have said West Texas, that's why.
Because I think it quite often depends on people.
I thought West Texas, before we moved to El Paso, began with the interstate that goes through Austin.
I agree, yeah.
When I got to El Paso, they were saying, no, no, no, West Texas is everything this side of Odessa.
Did they?
Isn't that funny?
See, it depends on where.
And they thought East Texas began at Austin.
Isn't that interesting?
And I said, no, no.
Isn't that interesting?
So we agreed.
Let's see.
Dad's pet peeves, as you remember.
What could you do or anybody do that would really?
Not telling the truth.
Not telling the truth.
There was some incident when my brother and I, we were still living in Brady, and it had to do with leaving soap in the sink.
And the two of us had to stand in there until one confessed.
So truth telling absolutely was essential.
Ladies had to be ladylike.
I mentioned I loved to sew and I was always encouraged to sew with big family and my grandmother had taught me to sew on an old treadle machine.
I can remember being upstairs with my fabric, my feet spread out and cutting fabric between them.
And I can remember Dad really

not approving of the way that the young lady was sitting even though i was upstairs in the private area but being you know boys were supposed to be certain ways and girls were supposed to be certain ways all right now uh you mentioned a while ago that he said that he thought he smelled tobacco would it have been acceptable for you to start smoking as a youngster
No, no.
In fact, I had started smoking, and I never smoked around him.
And when the house burned in 63, some friends back at school said, oh, tell me you weren't smoking in the bathroom.
And I wasn't.
But, oh, no.
In fact, he offered, the deal was, and I don't know if it was with the younger kids, with my older brother and I, if we reached 21 and did not smoke, then he would give us $100.
And in 1963, that was a whole lot of money.
And it just happened that the same week that I turned 21, I was graduating from the University of Texas.
And so Mother and Dad came to graduation, and Dad hugged me, and he said, Sister, I've got $100 in my pocket.
And he pulled it out.
He said, Did you earn it?
And I said, No, sir, I didn't.
Did he say anything?
Not a word.
Did he act surprised?
Not a word.
That was it.
Okay.
That was it.
Let me share with you a Missouri version of that.
The legendary football coach up there was Don Farrow, F-A-U-R-O-T. Died three years ago, age 93.
Oh, my.
Never smoked, never drank.
Only strong language was hell and damn.
And I asked him what led him up to it.
And he said, well, I've got to go watch.
I said, well, I don't know what you mean.
He said, well, where I grew up, all the boys were church-going people, were told, if you won't smoke till you're 21, I'll give you a gold watch.
And he said to us, that was like a Cadillac.
He said, I and all my brothers got gold watches.
They also lived into their 80s and 90s.
Isn't that wonderful?
Yeah.
To my knowledge, I don't think Dad ever smoked a cigarette.
I never was aware of that.
I don't think even in the service.
I don't think he ever, ever did.
Now, my brother, who just stopped smoking a few years ago, I said, well, Bud, we were comparing notes.
We'd never compared notes.
And he said, I said, well, did you get your $100?
And he said, I sure did.
I said, well, you lied.
And he said, no, I didn't.
I just started smoking the next day.
All right.
Now, would it have been acceptable for you to drink beer or whiskey as a youngster?
Oh, no.
Okay.
That was it.
That was it.
But in a way, I was blessed with an easy spirit.
I mean, those were never things... Well, same for me.
I grew up in that same setting.
You know, I just...
There were certain rules.
Pleasing Mother and Dad was a lot more important to me than any of that other stuff.
All right, and see, I think I see also consistency of those attitudes in your family and what A&M...
50s, 60s was.
Situation's different in a whole bunch of ways now than then.
All right, let's go near the sad part.
Were you aware of any failure in your day?
Let me just mention one thing, too.
My son, when he was in med school in Dallas, would talk to high school and junior high kids.
And he would tell the story.
And he'd say, we always had to go, just my brother and me and mom.
But he said, we always had to go and kiss mother when we got home.
And she always took a deep breath.
So she knew what we had been doing.
Been there.
Anyway, so it does carry on.
Oh, let's see.
When you would come in from a date, somebody was still awake.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yes.
Mm-hmm.
Well, it wasn't that late.
No, no, but whether it was or was not.
Oh, sure.
Oh, sure.
Were you aware of any health problem your dad was having before his death?
I know that when he would go to the hospital, he didn't want visitors.
And I know that there were a few times when he would have spells.
See, we faculty types were not aware of it.
The Christmas before Dad died, I was in Michigan.
My son Mark and I had lost a first baby.
So the second baby was the first grandchild and was much loved and way too far away.
Dad insisted he wanted me home for Christmas.
And I can't remember all the circumstances, but I would have been able to come a month in early February and stay a long time.
And so I didn't come at Christmas.
Now that would have been Christmas of 69.
Of 69.
And then I got the call that he was in Houston and was very ill.
late January, I think last May 30th of January.
So it's almost like I wasn't aware that he was sick, but looking back on things, you know, you just think something was going on.
He had never, he had never been insistent like that, that I come home and bring the baby.
And also, I'm assuming, jumping to confusion again about Texas and real world,
I'm assuming that he thought of himself as a strong, able-bodied man.
He loved it.
He loved a hitsack.
Feel that.
Feel that.
He's got strong legs and hitsack.
Feel that muscle.
And even his arms.
Like heck I can't.
I'll show you that I can't.

The only time when I was pregnant after, again, having lost the first baby, I came home and I just was nearly pregnant, and that was when we had Ranger, the bulldog, and we were out at Carter Lake, and my brother and the dog were in Head Davis' little John boat, and I wanted to get in, and Dad said, Sister, don't get in.
I'm not sure I can jump in and save you.
So, you know, a few things like that, but never...
Before, and then sure enough the dog jumped in and drowned.
Let's digress on Ranger.
How old was Ranger, the dog?
We had several.
The only dogs we'd ever had were Bulldogs.
There's a picture of me with Dad getting off the Victory Loan train, and he comes off with this little Brendol Bulldog pup.
And from then on, that's all we had was Bulldogs.
But the dog that's buried on, that's Ranger.
Right.
Well, they were all rangers, except for one female with Lady.
Right.
Now, that's not the dog that you all brought here when you moved here, is it?
The one that's buried?
No.
No.
One died, and then the Corps gave my brother another one.
I really think it was that very last one that was such a character.
I think so.
I think so.
I think so.
And is buried there.
Now, whose idea was that?
Do you know?
No.
No.
Because I don't think it was your family's idea.
I think that was the Corps' idea or something.
Probably.
Because I think they had gifted Bob that dog.
Because if I'm not mistaken, that dog had just about the same privileges as Rebel.
Oh, and I think it had been fed so much that it had health problems and it had...
Was that the one that even operated on it?
Because, you know, bulldogs are notoriously hard to breathe because of their facial construction.
I think so.
All right, so you weren't aware of any approaching serious health problems on your dad.
All right, and then you got the call.
His blood pressure was high.
He worked too hard.
He didn't eat, you know, all of that.
Because now what I heard through the grapevine was,
combination of heart and kidney, and that each affected the other.
Those are things Mother could tell you.
The only time I became, I remember being aware of kidney problems were after he was in the hospital.
I wasn't aware of any kidney problems prior to that.
How long was he in the hospital?
He had apparently a stroke or cerebral hemorrhage.
I want to say it was January 30th.
And then he died March 23rd.
He was here just a day or two.
And then, how did I get home?
Maybe even Maggie, I know Maggie McGee came to get me in the tentacle plane when Dad died on that day.
And he may have done it even before that, when Dad was, I can't remember how I got home with Mark.
Now for me, as a young faculty member, the memorial service was the biggest gathering I'd ever seen of national leaders.
And that I remember, and that was an illustration of me, to me, of your father's...
I'd never met President Johnson before that.
I'd never met Mrs. Johnson.
I was so struck by their kindness.
I was struck by her beauty.
Yes, yes, yes, yes.
To this day, I can't walk into the first floor of the old systems building, of the Williams building, because that's where dad was.
They had him in the castle.
Let's see.
I'll tell you, Lady Bird Johnson, this is the first board meeting, regents meeting, after we got to UT El Paso.
Mrs. Johnson had just gone off the UT board

But she was invited to this dinner on Thursday night, and you'd go through, get your meal, and then we were having it at the Chancellor's Residence, and we go into the library, and here comes Mrs. Johnson.
So we go over and introduce ourselves, and I told her a story about when Linda Bird, as a freshman at Austin, came over here in the fall, I think it was 62, to Scoma to hear her father speak.
And the Corps commander at the event all-male Texas A&M took Linda Bird to eat lunch in Duncan Binding Hall a week after the Longhorns had massacred the Aggies on Thanksgiving Day.
And in the middle of the meal, at a given signal, every freshman jumped up and yelled, beat the hell out of TU.
Oh, no.
And they all then stopped and stared at her.
She slowly put her napkin on the table.
The room got very quiet.
She sat there a moment, then stood up, pushed the chair underneath the table, stared at the group, and then did hook on horn and yelled out, hook on horn.
And everybody stood and cheered for her.
And when I told Mrs. Johnson that, she smiled.
She said, that's my girl.
How's her health?
She can barely walk.
She then said, I begged my daughters not to marry a politician.
not to put their children through all the problems that we put them through.
But she said, Chuck has campaigning for governor.
I'll be up there in Richmond Monday to help him campaign.
And I thought, oh boy.
Now, your dad made these great changes here.
Are there some things that you thought
thought I was going to chat about that I have forgotten and have overlooked.
What are some other things that we should have covered that I haven't?
Gosh, you're so good at this.
How many are you going to interview?
Do you know all the total?
Oh, countless.
Dozens.
Oh, I've already done 50 some odd.
Have you really?
Yeah.
This will go on two or three, four years.
No, really, I just feel battling that I don't have...
more pertinent recollections.
But truly, I think the best thing my folks did for me was to kind of turn me loose once we got here.
Because I absolutely loved it.
Now, I don't remember your mother's health being ever, I always remember her in high gear.
She was in high gear.
The only problem she's had is she's had foot problems.
And she really, the walk, the standing and receiving lines was, I think, very difficult for her.
And...
But she and I played tennis until after we got here for years.
Now, let's see, in terms of the, did your dad enjoy Aggie athletics or was that a?
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
In fact, having been the football coach in Brady, and then as mayor, at the time we left there, he had been mayor of Brady.
Oh, sure.
And I just remember, I mean, he loved going there.
And for me, all my other friends were allowed to run and play.
And I had to sit, and I had to press up.
But other questions?
Other things that I haven't looked at, I forgot.
Well, if there are, when you get the typescript, please add them.
Thanks.
Like I said, I just loved my daddy.
I think that's it.
But let's close with this.
If he were here today, what do you think his opinion would be of Texas A&M as it is now?
That is one thing.

After you told me you wanted to come talk to me, one of the things I thought is that often, not often, but through the years, people have been very free about saying what daddy would or would not have done.
And the one thing my dad was not was predictable.
And so, I have really, to look at A&M, you just have to know that he would be pleased as punch.
But as far as opinion on specifics and stuff, he was never that predictable that I would even, I just, like we said early on,
of all the people I've known in my 57 almost years, he loved doing what he's doing.
He didn't, if he had complaints, he didn't verbalize them in my earshot.
And I just, I think if he could see what it has become, he would just be overwhelmed.
He deserves so much of the credit.
That's a great thing.
